VMX Documentation — Visual Matrix (Pro)

VMX is a budgeting alignment tool: you set scenario “bands” by category, VMX calculates cost allocation and flags categories that are under/over target ranges (guardrails). Compare two regions/typologies at the same tier, see delta drivers, and export a client-ready PDF + ZIP pack.

Includes: Hard Costs
Includes: Construction Indirects
Includes: Soft Costs
Includes: Cash Flow
Includes: Exports
Includes: Guardrails

Contents

Fast Start Core Concepts Workflow — Single Scenario Workflow — Compare Mode Guardrails & Status Delta Heat & Drivers Location & Typology Factors Land Acquisition Cost Soft Costs Escalation & Duration Cash Flow Draw Schedule Exports (PDF / Client Pack) Versioning & Data Provenance Appendix — Technical Notes
Tip: Use Ctrl/Cmd + F to search within this guide.

Fast Start (5 minutes)

  1. Set Area (sq ft).
  2. Select a Tier (Select / Reserve / Signature / Legacy).
  3. Pick Location and Typology for Scenario A (and Scenario B if Compare Mode).
  4. For each cost row, click a Band: Low / Medium / High.
  5. Review Allocation and Status flags (Below / In Range / Above).
  6. In Compare Mode, check Delta Heat (B − A) to see what’s driving the difference.
  7. Open Soft Costs + Escalation + Cash Flow to schedule escalation and draw profiling.
  8. Export using Export PDF Report (print-ready) or Export Client Pack (ZIP bundle).
Best practice — Make one change at a time. Adjust one category band, then check how totals and guardrail flags move.

Core Concepts

ConceptMeaningWhy it matters
Band (Low/Medium/High) Per-category $/sf selection driven by the benchmark dataset. Defines spend density for each cost bucket at the selected tier/location.
Allocation (% of total) The category’s share of total Direct Hard Costs (and roll-ups). Allocation is compared against guardrails to detect budget imbalance.
Guardrails (targets) Expected % ranges for each category at the selected tier. Flags under/over-weighted categories early (before drawings lock).
Status Below / In Range / Above based on allocation vs. guardrail range. Provides a clean, executive view of budget health.
Construction Indirects General Conditions, GC Fee (O&P), GL Insurance, Construction Contingency. US luxury builds must include this layer to reflect bankable contract value.
Grand Total All-in project total (Direct Hard + Indirects + Soft Costs + Escalation + Land). The number that matters for client alignment and feasibility checks.

Workflow — Single Scenario

Use Single Scenario when you have one target location/typology and want to dial-in the budget profile.

  • Set Scenario A Location + Typology.
  • Choose bands for each category to reflect client intent (efficiency vs. materiality vs. complexity).
  • Validate guardrails: aim for mostly In Range, with intentional exceptions.
  • Review Construction Indirects (GCs / Fee / Insurance / Contingency) for realism.

Workflow — Compare Mode

Compare Mode is for “same tier, different place” decisions (e.g., California Waterfront vs. Colorado Hillside).

  • Enable Compare Mode and set Scenario B Location + Typology.
  • Keep tier matched, then study Delta Heat (B − A).
  • Use the Drivers panel to explain why totals diverge (MEP load, foundations, sitework, etc.).

Guardrails & Status

Guardrails compare each category’s allocation against expected ranges for the tier.

  • Below Range — risk of underfunding (quality / scope mismatch).
  • Above Range — risk of bloat or misclassification.
  • In Range — healthy distribution for the chosen tier.
Interpretation — a flagged row is not “wrong”; it’s a conversation. For example, a Legacy tier can legitimately run higher Services (MEP) for advanced technologies.

Delta Heat & Drivers

Delta Heat visualizes the difference between Scenario B and Scenario A by category. Driver sorting can prioritize either Impact (|Δ Cost|) or Category order.

  • Large positive deltas typically come from Substructure, Site Prep, and External Works when typology is Hillside/Waterfront.
  • High-cost regions increase labor/logistics across the board — with damping for Finishes and FF&E where appropriate.

Location & Typology Factors

VMX applies a Location Factor from a dropdown (National Avg, Florida, California, Colorado, New York, etc.), then applies Typology Modifiers (Hillside, Waterfront, Urban, Rural, Desert).

High-Cost Location Damping

If Location Factor is greater than 1.10, Categories 4 (Interiors / Finishes) and 5 (FF&E) use a damped multiplier:
Category Multiplier = 1 + ((Global − 1) × 0.5)

Why damping exists — labor-heavy buckets should move more with location than imported furniture. VMX keeps the estimate believable without inflating items that don’t scale linearly.

Land Acquisition Cost

Land cost is captured per scenario and included in the final rollup.

  • Land is shown in headers and included in Grand Total (All-in).
  • In Compare Mode, each scenario keeps independent land values.

Soft Costs

Soft costs cover owner-side professional fees and statutory requirements (design team, permits, surveys, etc.).

  • Typical soft costs scale with complexity and duration.
  • Soft contingency is separate from construction contingency.

Escalation & Duration

Escalation models cost growth across the project schedule. Use duration to reflect market conditions and procurement realities.

Guidance — Early estimates should include escalation, then compress later as packages are bid and locked.

Cash Flow Draw Schedule

Cash flow maps spend over time so owner/family office can forecast liquidity.

  • Use a front-loaded curve for heavy early enabling works and shell.
  • Use a tail-heavy curve for interiors, FF&E, and final external works.

Exports (PDF / Client Pack)

VMX exports are designed for downstream teams: architect, interior design, owner’s rep, and GC.

  • PDF Report — print-ready snapshot with scenario headers, tables, and flags.
  • Client Pack (ZIP) — includes the PDF plus table snapshots for meetings / email circulation.
Tip — Always set Client + Project Name before exporting.

Versioning & Data Provenance

VMX is benchmark-driven. Treat exports as dated snapshots for governance.

  • Record dataset name and last updated date.
  • Keep a trail of scenario inputs when comparing revisions.

Appendix — Technical Notes

  • Elemental structure aligns to US Uniformat-style buckets for early-stage budgeting.
  • Construction Indirects are calculated separately from Direct Hard Costs to avoid double counting.
  • Location factors and typology modifiers are meant for early-stage directional modeling, not bid-level pricing.

End of guide.
